title: ying to children
intro: Listen to a discussion about the lies that parents tell children and whether that's a good or bad thing - and learn some useful vocabulary too.
this_week_question: According to a study by a US psychologist, what percentage of people will lie in a typical ten minute conversation?
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: a lie we tell without meaning to hurt someone
changing or bending of the truth
doing something deliberately to be cruel or to hurt someone.
accepted or ‘normal’ way something is done in society

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Neil.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And I'm Rob.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Rob, when you were a child, did you have a pet?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, we had a few pets. My favourite was a little fluffy hamster.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And what happened to your hamster?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well one day I got home from school and he wasn’t in his cage. I was worried for a bit in case he’d escaped or got hurt, but it was alright. My mum told me that he had gone to live on a farm so that he could run around with other animals.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Really?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, really.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: A hamster. Went to live on a farm. To be with other animals. Really?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Oh, well, when you put it like that.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I think that was probably one of those lies that parents tell their children so as not to make them sad.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well I’m sad now

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well maybe having a go at this quiz will cheer you up. According to a study by a US psychologist, what percentage of people will lie in a typical ten minute conversation?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I think most people don’t lie that much, so I’ll say 40%.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: We’ll reveal the answer a little later in the programme.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So today we are talking about lies and particularly the lies that parents tell children.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The topic was discussed on the BBC Radio 4 programme, Woman’s Hour.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: A guest on that programme was Doctor Chris Boyle, a psychologist at Exeter University. He talks about a particular kind of lie. We tell these lies not because we want to hurt people. What colour are these lies called?

transcript.author: Dr Chris Boyle
transcript.text: A white lie is just a distortion of the truth without malicious intent – as long as there's not malicious intent I think it's something that we do. It's almost a societal norm that it's become where it is acceptable that we do tell certain lies at certain times.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Dr Chris Boyle there. What colour is the kind of lie he was talking about?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: A white lie . He says a white lie is just a distortion of the truth. Distortion here means a changing or bending of the truth. These kind of lies are OK as long as we don’t tell them because we want to hurt someone.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: He used the phrase malicious intent to talk about a bad reason for doing something, didn’t he?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, intent is the reason or purpose for doing something and malicious is an adjective which means cruel or nasty. So without malicious intent means without wanting to hurt or be cruel to someone.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: He said that this kind of white lie was almost a societal norm . Can you explain what he means by that?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, something that is the norm is something that is expected, it’s regular and usual.The adjective societal comes from the noun society. So a societal norm is something that is regular and common in your culture or society.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So do you think your mum’s story about the hamster and the farm was a little white lie?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, I’m sure it was. She didn’t do it with malicious intent - she didn’t want to hurt me. In fact, just the opposite, she wanted to protect me.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, that’s one kind of white lie that parents tell, to protect children. There are also a couple of other reasons. One being the parent’s convenience.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, I remember my mum telling me on certain days, the park wasn’t open. I know now that it never closed, I guess at the time she was just too busy to take me.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And then there are the cultural lies that parents tell children.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: What do you mean by that?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well first, if you have any children listening to this right now, you might want to cover their ears for a few seconds. RobI’m talking about, for example, Father Christmas and the Tooth Fairy.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, there’s no malicious intent in telling children those stories. It is a cultural and societal norm.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Let’s listen to Dr Chris Boyle again talking about white lies .

transcript.author: Dr Chris Boyle
transcript.text: Dr Chris Boyle A white lie is just a distortion of the truth without malicious intent – as long as there's not malicious intent I think it's something that we do. It's almost a societal norm that it's become where it is acceptable that we do tell certain lies at certain times.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So now back to our question at the top of the programme. I asked what percentage of people will lie in a typical ten minute conversation. Was it:

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I said a) just 40%.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well I'm afraid the answer was 60%.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Really? Goodness 60%! That's more than I expected.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Right, well before we go, let’s recap the vocabulary we talked about today. The first expression was ' white lie'. A lie we tell without meaning to hurt someone, for example when I say to you – you look nice today!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Wait, what did you say?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But that is actually a distortion of the truth. A changing or bending of the truth.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Mmmm. This makes me think of the next expression, ' malicious intent' . Intent is the reason or purpose for doing something, and doing something with a malicious intent is doing it deliberately to be cruel or to hurt someone. I think you have a malicious intent , telling me that when you say I look nice, it’s just a lie!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I’m just kidding!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: That’s the norm for you, isn’t it, just kidding. A ' norm' is the standard or ‘normal’ way that something is. In the clip we heard ' societal norm' whichis the accepted or ‘normal’ way something is done in society.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: For example, telling children about Father Christmas.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Sssh! But yes you're right.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, sadly this isn’t a lie but that's all for this programme. For more, find us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and our YouTube pages, and of course our website bbclearningenglish.com where you can find all kinds of other audio programmes, videos, and quizzes, to help you improve your English. Thanks for joining us and goodbye!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Bye.
